one_liner: Spiky crowns, fuels eighty per cent of mezcal production.
Small piñas on rocky hillsides, hand-cut, valued.
Hard to find, slow to grow, needs up to twenty five years.
Slim, tall towers of narrow leaves up to eight feet tall.
Fat cylinder piñas squat in low valleys, built tough.
Slender, graceful leaves cling to steep slopes, lean and lithe.
Tall stalk, crown on top, hangs out on dry roadsides
Tall and cane-like, sharp tips and a skyward stance.
Red leaf bases, green blades, bold contrast.
Thick, toothed leaves built for mountain weather.
Pale, dusty leaves, tiny teeth, twenty-year wait.
Toothy edges, big rosette, often up to ten feet wide
Toothy margins, spiky rosette, blades for leaves.
Rigid leaf rays, green all the way to the tips.
Jagged-edged leaves built for rocky slopes.
Winglike leaves, wavy edges, and sharp, orange tips.
Crown of spines with a bold, sky-reaching silhouette.
Fleshy, broad leaves on a seriously wide rosette.
Armor in plant form, edge to tip, teeth and spine.
Silver leaves haunt rocky ground, twenty years to grow.
Long, barbed leaves guard a stout piña, harvest takes care.
Named for Mitla’s Zapotec ‘place of rest’ on limestone.
Blue-gray lances with teeth down the edge.
A familiar blue (tequila) agave, seen from a new angle.
Slow-growing green rosette, ten to twenty years to size.
Six feet tall, spreads wide, green turns grey blue
Steel blue rosette, stiff blades with toothed edges.
Sword like leaves stay tough in dry heat and sandy soils.
Narrow leaves that look like a spire in the wind
A patient agave, pined and rooted, built to stay put.
Low, stocky spines curl like tusks in valley floors and slopes.
Light green, curvy blades with a rough, grippy feel.
Slender, arching leaves with calm, clean lines.
Light toned rosettes, known for threadlike white filaments
A tight rosette of blades, finished with a sharp spine.
Scarce by nature, it shows up as a rare surprise pour.
A tight rosette of flat leaves, armed edge to edge.
Chontal mountain maguey, hummingbird bait.
A broad leather-leaved giant that can top ten feet.
A classic century-plant silhouette: wide, stiff, spiky.
